statements.name: PROC CQLIM
statements.description: The CQLIM procedure is a version of the QLIM procedure in SAS/ETS software that requires SAS Cloud Analytic Services in order to run. Both procedures analyze univariate limited dependent variable models in which dependent variables take discrete values or are observed within only a limited range of values. Unlike the QLIM procedure, which can be run only on a single workstation, the CQLIM procedure takes advantage of a distributed computing environment that enables it to distribute the optimization task to one or more nodes. In addition, each node can use one or more threads to perform the optimization on its subset of the data. When several nodes are used and each node uses several threads to carry out its part of the work, the result is a highly parallel computation that can provide a dramatic gain in performance.

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Prints the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Prints the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVEST=
arguments.description: Specifies the method to calculate the covariance matrix of parameter estimates. By default, COVEST=HESSIAN.

arguments.name: OP
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product matrix.

arguments.name: HESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: QML
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance from the outer product and Hessian matrices (the quasi-maximum likelihood estimates).

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the input SAS data set. If you omit this option, PROC CQLIM uses the most recently created SAS data set.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Prints the initial parameter estimates, convergence criteria, and all constraints of the optimization. At each iteration, objective function value, step size, maximum gradient, and slope of search direction are also printed.

statements.name: BOUNDS
statements.description: The BOUNDS statement imposes simple boundary constraints on the parameter estimates. BOUNDS statement constraints refer to the parameters estimated by the QLIM procedure. Any number of BOUNDS statements can be specified. Each bound is composed of parameters and constants and inequality operators. Parameters associated with regressor variables are referred to by the names of the corresponding regressor variables: item operator item < operator item < operator item ...> > Each item is a constant, the name of a parameter, or a list of parameter names. Each operator is ’<’, ’>’, ’≤’, or ’≥’.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: A BY statement can be used with PROC CQLIM to obtain separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The CLASS statement names the classification variables to be used as explanatory variables in the analysis.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Reverses the sort order of the classification variable. If both the DESCENDING and ORDER= options are specified, PROC BCHOICE orders the categories according to the ORDER= option and then reverses that order.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values (., ._, .A, …, .Z for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid values for the CLASS variable.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the sort order for the levels of classification variables. This ordering determines which parameters in the model correspond to each level in the data. By default, ORDER=FORMATTED. For ORDER=FORMATTED and ORDER=INTERNAL, the sort order is machine-dependent. When ORDER=FORMATTED is in effect for numeric variables for which you have supplied no explicit format, the levels are ordered by their internal values.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the descending frequency count (levels that have more observations come ealier in the order).

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Levels sorted by the unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: PARAM=
arguments.description: Specifies the parameterization method for the classification variable or variables.
arguments.help: PARAM=EFFECT | GLM | ORDINAL | POLYNOMIAL | REFERENCE | ORTHEFFECT | ORTHORDINAL | ORTHPOLY | ORTHREF

arguments.name: EFFECT
arguments.description: Specifies effect coding.

arguments.name: GLM
arguments.description: Specifies less-than-full-rank, reference-cell coding; this option can be used only as a global option.

arguments.name: ORDINAL
arguments.description: Specifies the cumulative parameterization for an ordinal CLASS variable.

arguments.name: POLYNOMIAL
arguments.description: Specifies polynomial coding.

arguments.name: REFERENCE
arguments.description: Specifies reference-cell coding.

arguments.name: ORTHEFFECT
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=EFFECT.

arguments.name: ORTHORDINAL
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=ORDINAL.

arguments.name: ORTHPOLY
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=POLYNOMIAL.

arguments.name: ORTHREF
arguments.description: Orthogonalizes PARAM=REFERENCE.

arguments.name: REFERENCE=
arguments.description: Specifies the reference level that is used when you specify a nonsingular parameterization.

arguments.name: 'level'
arguments.description: Specifies the level of the variable to use as the reference level. Specify the formatted value of the variable if a format is assigned. Replace <level> with an actual value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first ordered level as reference.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last ordered level as reference.

statements.name: ENDOGENOUS
statements.description: The ENDOGENOUS statement specifies the type of dependent variables that appear on the left-hand side of the equation. Endogenous variables listed refer to the dependent variables that appear on the left-hand side of the equation. Currently, no right-hand side endogeneity is handled in PROC QLIM. All variables appearing on the right-hand side of the equation are treated as exogenous

arguments.name: CENSORED
arguments.description: Censors the endogenous variables in this statement. You can specify the following censored-options: LB=value | variable LOWERBOUND=value | variable specifies the lower bound of the censored variables. If value is missing or the value in variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: COST
arguments.description: [frontier-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Specifies that the estimated model be a cost function.

arguments.name: DISCRETE
arguments.description: Specifies that the endogenous variables in this statement be discrete. You can specify the following discrete-options: DISTRIBUTION=NORMAL|LOGISTIC DIST=NORMAL|LOGISTIC D=NORMAL|LOGISTIC specifies the cumulative distribution function used to model the response probabilities. Valid values are as follows: NORMAL the normal distribution for the probit model

arguments.name: DISTRIBUTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the cumulative distribution function to use to model the response probabilities.

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: specifies the logistic distribution for the logit model.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: specifies the normal distribution for the probit model.

arguments.name: FRONTIER
arguments.description: Specifies the stochastic frontier model. You can specify the following frontier-options: COST specifies that the estimated model be a cost function. PRODUCTION specifies that the estimated model be a production function. TYPE=HALF | EXPONENTIAL | TRUNCATED HALF specifies a half-normal model. EXPONENTIAL specifies an exponential model. TRUNCATED specifies a truncated normal model.

arguments.name: LOWERBOUND=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower bound of the censored or truncated variables. If value is missing or the value of variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: PRODUCTION
arguments.description: [frontier-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Specifies that the estimated model be a production function.

arguments.name: TRUNCATED
arguments.description: Truncates the endogenous variables in the statement. You can specify the following truncated-options: LB=value | variable LOWERBOUND=value | variable specifies the lower bound of the truncated variables. If value is missing or the value in variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: TYPE
arguments.description: Specifies the model type.

arguments.name: EXPONENTIAL
arguments.description: Specifies an exponential model.

arguments.name: HALF
arguments.description: Specifies a half-normal model.

arguments.name: TRUNCATED
arguments.description: Specifies a truncated normal model.

arguments.name: UPPERBOUND=
arguments.description: Specifies the upper bound of the censored or truncated variables. If value is missing or the value of variable is missing, no upper bound is set. By default, no upper bound is set.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: The FREQ statement identifies a variable that contains the frequency of occurrence of each observation. PROC CQLIM treats each observation as if it appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation. If it is not an integer, the frequency value is truncated to an integer. If the frequency value is less than 1 or missing, the observation is not used in the model fitting. When the FREQ statement is not specified, each observation is assigned a frequency of 1. If you specify more than one FREQ statement, then the first FREQ statement is used.

statements.name: HETERO
statements.description: The HETERO statement specifies variables that are related to the heteroscedasticity of the residuals and the way these variables are used to model the error variance.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: The functional form can be specified using the LINK= option.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Specifies a exponential link function.

arguments.name: LINEAR
arguments.description: Specifies a linear link function.

arguments.name: NOCONST
arguments.description: Specifies that there be no constant in the linear or exponential heteroscedasticity model.

arguments.name: SQUARE
arguments.description: Estimates the model by using the square of linear heteroscedasticity function.

statements.name: INIT
statements.description: The INIT statement is used to set initial values for parameters in the optimization. You can specify any number of INIT statements. Each initvalue is written as a parameter or parameter list, followed by an optional equality operator (=), followed by a number: parameter <=> number

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: The MODEL statement specifies the dependent variable and independent regressor variables for the regression model.

arguments.name: CENSORED
arguments.description: Censors the endogenous variables in this statement. You can specify the following censored-options: LB=value | variable LOWERBOUND=value | variable specifies the lower bound of the censored variables. If value is missing or the value in variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: COST
arguments.description: [frontier-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Specifies that the estimated model be a cost function.

arguments.name: DISCRETE
arguments.description: Specifies that the endogenous variables in this statement be discrete. You can specify the following discrete-options: DISTRIBUTION=NORMAL|LOGISTIC DIST=NORMAL|LOGISTIC D=NORMAL|LOGISTIC specifies the cumulative distribution function used to model the response probabilities. Valid values are as follows: NORMAL the normal distribution for the probit model

arguments.name: DISTRIBUTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the cumulative distribution function to use to model the response probabilities.

arguments.name: LOGISTIC
arguments.description: specifies the logistic distribution for the logit model.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: specifies the normal distribution for the probit model.

arguments.name: FRONTIER
arguments.description: Specifies the stochastic frontier model. You can specify the following frontier-options: COST specifies that the estimated model be a cost function. PRODUCTION specifies that the estimated model be a production function. TYPE=HALF | EXPONENTIAL | TRUNCATED HALF specifies a half-normal model. EXPONENTIAL specifies an exponential model. TRUNCATED specifies a truncated normal model.

arguments.name: LOWERBOUND=
arguments.description: Specifies the lower bound of the censored or truncated variables. If value is missing or the value of variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept parameter.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: [order-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Specifies the sort order for the levels of the discrete variables that you specify in the ENDOGENOUS statement. The sort order determines which parameters in the model correspond to each level in the data.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Sorts levels by formatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Sorts levels by descending frequency count; levels that have the most observations come first in the order.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Sorts levels by unformatted value. The sort order is machine-dependent.

arguments.name: PRODUCTION
arguments.description: [frontier-option to be enclosed in parenthesis] Specifies that the estimated model be a production function.

arguments.name: TRUNCATED
arguments.description: Truncates the endogenous variables in the statement. You can specify the following truncated-options: LB=value | variable LOWERBOUND=value | variable specifies the lower bound of the truncated variables. If value is missing or the value in variable is missing, no lower bound is set. By default, no lower bound is set.

arguments.name: TYPE
arguments.description: Specifies the model type.

arguments.name: EXPONENTIAL
arguments.description: Specifies an exponential model.

arguments.name: HALF
arguments.description: Specifies a half-normal model.

arguments.name: TRUNCATED
arguments.description: Specifies a truncated normal model.

arguments.name: UPPERBOUND=
arguments.description: Specifies the upper bound of the censored or truncated variables. If value is missing or the value of variable is missing, no upper bound is set. By default, no upper bound is set.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set containing all variables in the input data set and, optionally, the estimates of x'β, predicted value, residual, marginal effects, probability, standard deviation of the error, expected value, conditional expected value, and inverse Mills ratio. When the response values are missing for the observation, all output estimates except residual are still computed as long as none of the explanatory variables is missing. This enables you to compute these statistics for prediction. You can specify only one OUTPUT statement.

arguments.name: CONDITIONAL
arguments.description: Output estimates of conditional expected values of continuous endogenous

arguments.name: COPYVAR=
arguments.description: Adds any SAS variables that appear in the input data set to the output data set.

arguments.name: ERRSTD
arguments.description: Output estimates of σ-j, the standard deviation of the error term.

arguments.name: EXPECTED
arguments.description: Output estimates of expected values of continuous endogenous variables.

arguments.name: MARGINAL
arguments.description: Output marginal effects.

arguments.name: MILLS
arguments.description: Output estimates of inverse Mills ratios of censored or truncated continuous, binary discrete, and selection endogenous variables.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set.

arguments.name: PREDICTED
arguments.description: Output estimates of predicted endogenous variables.

arguments.name: PROB
arguments.description: Output estimates of probability of discrete endogenous variables taking the current observed responses.

arguments.name: PROBALL
arguments.description: Output estimates of probability of discrete endogenous variables for all possible responses.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL
arguments.description: Output estimates of residuals of continuous endogenous variables.

arguments.name: TE1
arguments.description: Outputs estimates of technical efficiency for each producer in the stochastic frontier model suggested by Battese and Coelli (1988).

arguments.name: TE2
arguments.description: Outputs estimates of technical efficiency for each producer in the stochastic frontier model suggested by Jondrow et al. (1982).

arguments.name: XBETA
arguments.description: Output estimates of x'β.

statements.name: RESTRICT
statements.description: The RESTRICT statement is used to impose linear restrictions on the parameter estimates. Any number of RESTRICT statements can be specified, but the number of restrictions imposed is limited by the number of regressors. Each restriction is written as an expression, followed by an equality operator (=) or an inequality operator (<, >, ≤, ≥), followed by a second expression: expression operator expression The operator can be =, <, >, ≤ , or ≥. The operator and second expression are optional.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement performs Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests of linear hypotheses about the regression parameters in the preceding MODEL statement. Each equation specifies a linear hypothesis to be tested. All hypotheses in one TEST statement are tested jointly. Variable names in the equations must correspond to regressors in the preceding MODEL statement, and each name represents the coefficient of the corresponding regressor. The keyword INTERCEPT refers to the coefficient of the intercept.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests Wald, Lagrange multiplier, and likelihood ratio tests.

arguments.name: LM
arguments.description: Requests the Lagrange multiplier test.

arguments.name: LR
arguments.description: Requests the likelihood ratio test.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Requests the Wald test.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement specifies a variable to supply weighting values to use for each observation in estimating parameters. The log likelihood for each observation is multiplied by the corresponding weight variable value. If the weight of an observation is nonpositive, that observation is not used in the estimation.

arguments.name: NONORMALIZE
arguments.description: Specifies that the weights must be used as is. When you omit this option, the weights are normalized so that they add up to the actual sample size.
